title: 115_hr3044
content: Expanding supplemental benefits for chronically ill Medicare Advantage enrollees. Expanding supplemental benefits for chronically ill Medicare Advantage enrollees by allowing MA plans to provide additional benefits starting in 2020. Supplemental benefits for chronically ill Medicare Advantage enrollees must aim to improve or maintain health and overall function, not limited to solely health-related benefits. The Secretary has the authority to waive uniformity requirements for these benefits. The Secretary can waive uniformity requirements for supplemental benefits provided to chronically ill Medicare Advantage enrollees, defined as those with life-threatening or significantly limiting chronic conditions. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on supplemental benefits for Medicare Advantage enrollees with chronic conditions that significantly limit health or function, pose a high risk of adverse outcomes, or require intensive care coordination. The study will analyze the utilization and impact of supplemental benefits on Medicare Advantage enrollees with chronic conditions, including the quality of care received and the utilization of services under the original Medicare fee-for-service program. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of supplemental benefits on Medicare Advantage enrollees with chronic conditions, including care quality and service utilization. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment.
